questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started on the face and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, he has had a mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis and occasional asthma attacks. Two weeks ago, he was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. He emigrated with his family from Japan 3 weeks ago. His immunization status is unknown. He appears well. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. His palms and soles show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measles typically manifest in two stages. The prodromal stage is characterized by a classic triad of coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis in combination with Koplik spots. It is followed by an exanthem stage in which patients usually develop a high fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem that spreads from the face to the entire body. This patient's low-grade fever, postauricular lymphadenopathy, good general condition, and nonconfluent rash are not characteristic of measles.
Image Description:

Multiple maculopapular blanching and partially confluent patches are disseminated over the head, neck, and back of this young patient.

These findings are consistent with a desquamating rash, which can occur after fading of the first erythematous exanthema, caused by an infection with the measles virus.

B) INCORRECT:

Exanthem subitum usually manifests in patients between 6 months and 2 years of age, with almost all children being seropositive by the age of three. The typical presentation begins with a febrile phase, with abrupt onset high fever, cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy, inflamed tympanic membranes, and papular enanthem on the uvula and soft palate (Nagayama spots). After 2–3 days, patients subsequently develop a sudden decrease in temperature and a patchy, rose-pink, confluent, blanching, maculopapular exanthem that begins on the trunk and can spread to the face and extremities. The rash usually fades within a few hours to 2 days and can therefore easily go unnoticed. The patient's age, history of a progressive rash for 2 days, and the finding of a nonconfluent exanthem make another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Photograph of a 9-month-old infant with recent high fever

A patchy, macular exanthem is visible on the trunk, neck, and behind the ears. Symptoms developed after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with mild nonspecific symptoms (sore throat, low-grade fever, conjunctivitis, headache) and post-auricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy, followed by a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash, all of which suggest Rubella infection. The exanthem typically begins on the head and spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. During the prodromal phase, a maculopapular enanthem on the soft palate (Forchheimer sign) may be present.

Rubella was officially eliminated in the US in 2004 by widespread vaccination. However, sporadic cases may occur in unimmunized individuals with a recent history of migration to the US or travel to a country with a higher prevalence of the disease. While rubella is usually self-limited and has a benign course, infection during pregnancy can lead to congenital rubella syndrome, with cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and heart defects in the neonate.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic drug reactions often present as a type IV hypersensitivity with a red, blanching maculopapular rash beginning on the head, then spreading to the trunk and extremities. While almost any oral medication can result in an allergic reaction, common causes are allopurinol, phenytoin, penicillin, and sulfa antibiotics. The exanthem usually begins 5–14 days after the medication has been initiated and may involve the palms, soles, and mucous membranes. Although this patient was treated with penicillin two weeks ago, the presence of lymphadenopathy without pruritus makes another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with scarlet fever, an initial phase with fever, tonsillopharyngitis, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea) is usually followed by a scarlet‑colored maculopapular, blanching exanthem with a sandpaper-like texture. The rash typically begins on the neck and subsequently spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. Characteristic findings of scarlet fever are Pastia's lines, perioral pallor, and a strawberry tongue. After resolution of the rash, the skin typically desquamates in flakes, exposing new and tender epidermis. The examination findings presented in the case above are not consistent with those of scarlet fever.
Image Description:

The typical scarlet-colored, fine, maculopapular exanthem of scarlet fever is seen on the right arm. Flushed cheeks and perioral pallor are also evident.

F) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome usually begins 1–3 weeks after initiation of a medication (e.g., aminopenicillins, sulfonamides, allopurinol) and manifests with a high fever, myalgia, and a sore throat followed by mucocutaneous lesions. Skin findings include erythematous macules with a targetoid appearance, bullae and/or vesicles, epidermal necrosis, and sloughing. Involvement of the mucosal membranes is very common and leads to stomatitis, conjunctivitis with photophobia, dysphagia, diarrhea, and various other symptoms. The patient's presentation is not consistent with Stevens-Johnson syndrome; a different diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with erythema infectiosum typically present with mild flu-like symptoms followed by a rash. The exanthem usually begins in the face as a “slapped-cheek rash” with perioral sparing and subsequently spreads to the trunk and extremities. Adults in particular often present with additional symptoms of arthralgia and symmetrical polyarthritis. The examination findings, in this case, are not consistent with erythema infectiosum.
Image Description:

The cheeks are bright red (slapped-cheek rash) and a diffuse, red, confluent rash with macules and papules is visible over the body of this infant.

This is the characteristic cutaneous appearance of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by infection with parvovirus B19.

H) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox can manifest with prodromes such as fever and malaise; however, a rash is typically the first sign of infection. The exanthem typically starts on the trunk and subsequently spreads to the entire body, including the scalp and in some cases affecting the oral and urogenital mucosa, as well as the palms and soles. It is characterized by the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash (e.g., papules, vesicles, crusts) and severe pruritus. This patient's maculopapular rash is not consistent with chickenpox.
Image Description:

Upper body of a young boy with exanthem showing the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash; mainly vesicles and pustules, no crusted erosions. This clinical finding is also referred to as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.
questions.hint: Older patients with this condition often present with polyarthritis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old gravida 2, para 1 comes to the physician because she has had an itchy rash all over her body for the past 3 days. It started on her face and gradually progressed downwards. She reports painless swelling of her knee joints and denies trauma. She had flu-like symptoms 3–4 days prior to the appearance of the rash. She has received no prenatal care. She delivered her first child vaginally without complications. She takes an iron supplement; her immunization records are unavailable. Examination shows a pink maculopapular rash over her body sparing her palms and soles. Postauricular lymphadenopathy is present. Knee joints are mildly swollen and range of motion is normal. Examination shows a uterus consistent with a 24-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of chickenpox (varicella zoster), which may cause congenital varicella syndrome. Chickenpox manifests with an itchy rash and a flu-like prodrome. This patient has a maculopapular rash instead of a vesiculopustular rash at different stages at once, the latter being typical for chickenpox. Additionally, the rash in chickenpox starts on the trunk, not on the face.

B) INCORRECT:

Counseling about the potentially devastating effects on the fetus and the possibility of terminating the pregnancy is indicated if maternal rubella infection occurs during the first trimester. The risk of congenital rubella syndrome is extremely low (< 1%) if fetal rubella infection occurs after 16 weeks of gestation. Given the incubation period of rubella infection (2–3 weeks) and the fact that clinical features of maternal rubella infection occurred at 24 weeks of gestation, it is safe to assume that this patient could have, at worst, acquired the infection at 21 weeks of gestation. Termination of pregnancy is therefore not recommended in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The rubella vaccine (MMR vaccine) is a live vaccine and is, therefore, contraindicated during pregnancy. Furthermore, vaccination would not be helpful for this patient who already has the condition. The MMR vaccine should, however, be administered to all nonpregnant women of childbearing age who have an unknown vaccination history or are seronegative for rubella-specific IgG.

D) CORRECT:

Rubella infection in a pregnant woman can put the fetus at risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome, especially during the first trimester. After the 16th week of gestation, however, the risk of developing congenital defects is very low; reassurance and symptomatic therapy (e.g., acetaminophen) are usually recommended. If rubella infection occurred before 16 weeks of gestation, the patient should be counseled about the potentially devastating effects on the fetus and the possibility of terminating the pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

If a pregnant woman is exposed to a patient with rubella, passive immunization with intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG) within 5 days of exposure can prevent maternal rubella infection. However, routine administration of IVIG is not recommended if rubella infection has already become symptomatic. In addition, while it may reduce maternal symptoms, IVIG does not prevent congenital rubella syndrome. As this patient has mild symptoms and is already in the 24th week of her pregnancy, this intervention is not indicated.
questions.hint: An itchy maculopapular rash that started on the face and spread to the rest of the body but spares the palms and soles, in combination with postauricular lymphadenopathy and polyarthritis, is highly suggestive of rubella.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a fever and rash for 2 days. The rash started on her head and then spread to her chest and arms. She did not receive all of her vaccinations. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 22/min. On examination, there is postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. An image of the rash is shown. The rash fades when the overlying skin is pressed. Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of the causal organism to other individuals?

choices.text: Require all staff and visitors to wear a surgical mask within 6 feet of the patient
Require all staff and visitors to wear gloves and a gown before entering the patient's room
Require all staff and visitors to wear an N95 respirator before entering the patient's room
Transfer the patient to a negative pressure room
No further isolation precautions are required

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rubella is a viral infection that is spread by droplet transmission. Therefore, in addition to following standard precautions (e.g., hand disinfection), all staff and visitors who interact with a patient with rubella should adopt droplet precautions, such as wearing a surgical mask when within 6 feet of the patient. The patient should be kept in isolation or patient cohorts (i.e., in a room with those who have the same illness), and a mask should be placed on the patient when the patient is transported out of their room for any reason.

Other diseases that require droplet precautions include Neisseria meningitidis, Bordetella pertussis, Haemophilus influenzae type b, and influenza virus infections. Droplet precautions should be in place until the end of the infectious period; i.e., 7 days after the onset of rash in the case of rubella.

B) INCORRECT:

In this patient with postnatal rubella, the use of gloves and a gown is required as a part of standard precautions (e.g., when performing procedures during which contact with body fluids is anticipated) but contact precautions (e.g., wearing gloves and a gown before entering the patient's room) are not required. Contact precautions are necessary for the care of patients who have diseases spread by contact transmission such as congenital rubella infection and varicella.

C) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions (e.g., wearing an N95 respirator) are necessary when caring for patients with diseases spread by airborne transmission such as measles and varicella, which commonly occur in patients whose vaccinations are not up-to-date. This patient has rubella, which does not require airborne precautions.

D) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions (e.g., isolating the patient in a negative pressure room) are necessary when caring for patients with diseases spread by airborne transmission such as measles and varicella, which most commonly occur in individuals whose vaccinations are not up-to-date. This patient has rubella, which does not require airborne precautions.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has rubella, which requires droplet precautions until the end of the infectious period (i.e., 7 days after the onset of rash). Patients with erythema infectiosum, on the other hand, are no longer considered contagious once the exanthem develops and do not require any further isolation precautions.
questions.hint: This patient, whose vaccinations are not up-to-date, presents with low-grade fever, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and a generalized erythematous, blanching, nonconfluent maculopapular rash with medium-sized spots, which are highly suggestive of rubella. The rash of rubella can manifest simultaneously with fever or up to 5 days after fever onset.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a progressive rash for 2 days. The rash started on the face and now involves the trunk and extremities. Over the past 4 days, he has had a mild sore throat, red, itchy eyes, and headache. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of tonsillitis. Two weeks ago, he was treated for tonsillitis that resolved with penicillin therapy. He emigrated with his family from Japan 3 weeks ago. His immunization status is unknown. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. His palms and soles show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measles typically manifest in two stages. The prodromal stage is characterized by a classic triad of coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis in combination with Koplik spots. It is followed by an exanthem stage in which patients usually develop a high fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem that spreads from the face to the entire body. This patient's low-grade fever, postauricular lymphadenopathy, good general condition, and nonconfluent rash are not characteristic of measles.

Multiple maculopapular blanching and partially confluent patches are disseminated over the head, neck, and back of this young patient.

These findings are consistent with a desquamating rash, which can occur after fading of the first erythematous exanthema, caused by an infection with the measles virus.

B) INCORRECT:

Exanthem subitum usually manifests in patients between 6 months and 2 years of age, with almost all children being seropositive by the age of three. The rash usually fades within a few hours to 2 days and can therefore easily go unnoticed. Image Description:

Photograph of a 9-month-old infant with recent high fever

A patchy, macular exanthem is visible on the trunk, neck, and behind the ears. Symptoms developed after the fever resolved.

These features are consistent with roseola infantum.

This patient presents with mild nonspecific symptoms (sore throat, low-grade fever, conjunctivitis, headache) and post-auricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy, followed by a nonconfluent, pink maculopapular rash, all of which suggest Rubella infection. The exanthem typically begins on the head and spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. During the prodromal phase, a maculopapular enanthem on the soft palate (Forchheimer sign) may be present.

Rubella was officially eliminated in the US in 2004 by widespread vaccination. While rubella is usually self-limited and has a benign course, infection during pregnancy can lead to congenital rubella syndrome, with cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and heart defects in the neonate.

Allergic drug reactions often present as a type IV hypersensitivity with a red, blanching maculopapular rash beginning on the head, then spreading to the trunk and extremities. The exanthem usually begins 5–14 days after the medication has been initiated and may involve the palms, soles, and mucous membranes. Although this patient was treated with penicillin two weeks ago, the presence of lymphadenopathy without pruritus makes another diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

In patients with scarlet fever, an initial phase with fever, tonsillopharyngitis, and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea) is usually followed by a scarlet‑colored maculopapular, blanching exanthem with a sandpaper-like texture. The rash typically begins on the neck and subsequently spreads to the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. Characteristic findings of scarlet fever are Pastia's lines, perioral pallor, and a strawberry tongue. After resolution of the rash, the skin typically desquamates in flakes, exposing new and tender epidermis. The examination findings presented in the case above are not consistent with those of scarlet fever.
Image Description:

The typical scarlet-colored, fine, maculopapular exanthem of scarlet fever is seen on the right arm. Flushed cheeks and perioral pallor are also evident.
questions.hint: Older patients with this condition often present with polyarthritis.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 2-day history of low-grade fever, runny nose, and mild cough. This morning, he developed a pink, maculopapular rash that began on his face and quickly spread to his trunk and arms. He has never received routine vaccinations. Physical examination shows mild conjunctivitis and tender lymph nodes behind his ears. There are no oral lesions.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rubella manifests with low-grade fever, runny nose, and mild cough, followed by a pink, maculopapular rash starting on the face and spreading to the trunk and extremities. Tender lymphadenopathy, especially in the posterior auricular region, is a distinguishing feature. Mild conjunctivitis further supports the diagnosis. The child's unvaccinated status increases susceptibility to rubella, which is characterized by this specific pattern of rash and lymphadenopathy.

Key learning point: Rubella is characterized by a prodrome of low-grade fever, malaise, conjunctivitis, coryza, and cough, followed by a rash that begins on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

B) INCORRECT:

Measles typically presents with high-grade fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots, which are absent here. Tender postauricular lymphadenopathy is not common in measles. The mild systemic symptoms and rash pattern in this patient do not align with the severe presentation of measles.

C) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum, caused by parvovirus B19, is characterized by a 'slapped-cheek' rash followed by a lacy rash on the extremities. It lacks the tender postauricular lymphadenopathy and conjunctivitis seen here. The rash pattern and the patient's unvaccinated status suggest a different viral exanthem.

D) INCORRECT:

Roseola, caused by human herpesvirus-6, usually affects infants and toddlers, presenting with high fever that resolves before a rash appears. The rash typically starts on the trunk, not the face. The low-grade fever, conjunctivitis, and lymphadenopathy in this patient do not match roseola's presentation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman at nine weeks of gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for her first prenatal visit. She reports receiving an MMR vaccine four weeks ago, unaware of her pregnancy. She is concerned about congenital rubella syndrome. She has no relevant past medical history. Laboratory tests confirm protective rubella IgG levels. Physical examination is normal.
What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding her pregnancy?

choices.text: Advise administering rubella immunoglobulin to reduce fetal infection risk
Advise that there is no increased fetal risk and proceed with routine prenatal care
Recommend immediate pregnancy termination due to high teratogenic risk
Recommend diagnostic amniocentesis for rubella PCR testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rubella immunoglobulin is not recommended for prophylaxis following MMR vaccination, as it does not alter outcomes. The patient has protective rubella IgG levels, indicating adequate immunity, making additional immunoglobulin unnecessary. The attenuated vaccine strain has not been associated with fetal harm.

B) CORRECT:

The MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, and while live vaccines are generally contraindicated in pregnancy, extensive data show that inadvertent rubella vaccination during early pregnancy does not lead to congenital rubella syndrome or fetal harm. This patient has protective rubella IgG levels, indicating immunity and eliminating the risk of natural rubella infection, which poses a higher risk to the fetus. Therefore, routine prenatal care is appropriate as the vaccination does not increase the risk of fetal malformations.

Key learning point: Inadvertent rubella vaccination during early pregnancy does not increase the risk of congenital rubella syndrome or adverse pregnancy outcomes, and a favorable pregnancy outcome is expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The MMR vaccine, although live attenuated, does not increase the risk of congenital anomalies when administered inadvertently during pregnancy. The patient has protective rubella IgG levels, indicating immunity and no rubella infection. Current guidelines do not support pregnancy termination based on vaccine exposure alone.

D) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis is invasive and reserved for suspected fetal anomalies or when prenatal diagnosis is indicated. The patient has protective rubella IgG levels, indicating immunity, and no evidence of active infection. Rubella PCR testing on amniotic fluid is not standard in cases of accidental live vaccination without signs of fetal compromise.

questions.text: An 11-year-old unvaccinated child presents with a 2-day history of low-grade fever and mild sore throat. She has prominent postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy and today developed a fine, pink, nonconfluent maculopapular rash that began behind her ears and has spread to her trunk and extremities, sparing her palms and soles. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer measles, mumps, rubella vaccine immediately
Perform throat culture for group A streptococcus
Obtain serology for rubella-specific IgM and IgG antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The measles, mumps, rubella vaccine should not be administered to patients with acute febrile illness or suspected active rubella infection. The vaccine is contraindicated during acute illness and would not be therapeutic for an ongoing active infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes virus infections, but this patient's presentation is consistent with rubella, which is caused by the rubella virus. Rubella management is primarily supportive, and antiviral therapy is not recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation (lymphadenopathy pattern, rash distribution, mild sore throat) strongly suggests rubella, not streptococcal infection.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation (postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy; fine, pink, nonconfluent maculopapular rash that began behind the ears and spread distally, sparing the palms and soles) strongly suggests rubella, warranting immediate diagnostic confirmation. Serology for rubella-specific IgM and IgG antibodies should be obtained in all patients with suspected rubella. RT-PCR should also be performed on a nasopharyngeal or throat swab as the patient presented within 7 days of rash onset.

E) INCORRECT:

Immediate discharge without diagnostic confirmation would be inappropriate due to the public health implications of rubella. Rubella is a nationally notifiable disease that must be immediately reported to local health departments, and patients should be counseled on isolation precautions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of low-grade fever, mild sore throat, and a fine pink rash that began on her face and has spread to her trunk and extremities. She reports joint pain in her wrists and knees that began yesterday. Physical examination shows nonconfluent, maculopapular lesions that have not affected the palms and soles and enlarged lymph nodes in the postauricular and suboccipital regions. She works at a daycare center and is uncertain about her vaccination history. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain rubella-specific IgM and IgG serology

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While rubella treatment is supportive, confirmation of the diagnosis is crucial before discharge due to the patient's occupation and the potential for transmission. Isolation precautions and contact tracing may be necessary. While supportive care is appropriate for rubella, the diagnosis must be confirmed before the patient is discharged to prevent transmission to children at her workplace. Isolation precautions and contact tracing may be necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is an antibiotic, which is inappropriate for a viral exanthem. This patient's clinical presentation is not consistent with a bacterial infection.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation (postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy; fine, pink, nonconfluent maculopapular rash that began behind the ears and spread distally, sparing the palms and soles; polyarthritis) strongly suggests rubella. Confirmation with rubella-specific IgM and IgG serology is essential given the patient's occupation and uncertain vaccination status, as confirmation is used to guide isolation precautions and contact tracing. For patients who present within 7 days of rash onset, RT-PCR of a throat or nasopharyngeal swab should be performed.

D) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral medication primarily used for herpes simplex virus and varicella-zoster virus infections. Acyclovir is not effective against rubella virus and is not indicated for this presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

The measles, mumps, rubella vaccine should not be administered during acute illness, and vaccination during the incubation period or early illness does not prevent disease. The vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy; pregnancy status should be determined before vaccination.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 18 weeks' gestation presents with a 3-day history of low-grade fever, mild conjunctivitis, and a fine pink maculopapular rash that began behind her ears and spread to her trunk. She works as a daycare teacher and reports that one of the children recently developed a similar rash. Physical examination shows tender postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. Her vaccination records are unavailable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with symptomatic care and routine prenatal follow-up
Place the patient in airborne isolation and obtain RT-PCR testing
Obtain rubella IgM and IgG serology before implementing any precautions
Implement standard and droplet precautions and immediately notify the health department
Admit for fetal monitoring and contact isolation precautions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharging a suspected rubella case without implementing infection control measures would allow continued transmission. Additionally, failure to notify public health authorities would violate reporting requirements for this nationally notifiable disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Airborne precautions are not indicated for rubella, which transmits via respiratory droplets rather than airborne particles. RT-PCR testing is appropriate for diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Serology is important for diagnosis, but infection control measures and public health notification cannot be delayed pending laboratory results. Rubella is immediately reportable upon clinical suspicion.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Suspected rubella requires immediate implementation of standard and droplet precautions due to respiratory droplet transmission. As a nationally notifiable disease, suspected cases must be reported immediately to the local health department without waiting for laboratory confirmation. The combination of clinical presentation and exposure history warrants immediate action.

E) INCORRECT:

Contact isolation is not required for rubella transmission, which occurs through respiratory droplets. While pregnancy adds complexity to the case, immediate admission for fetal monitoring is not the priority.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 18 weeks' gestation presents with a 3-day history of low-grade fever; mild conjunctivitis; and a fine, pink, maculopapular rash that began behind her ears and has spread to her trunk. She works as a daycare teacher and reports that one of the children recently developed a similar rash. Physical examination shows tender, postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. Her vaccination records are unavailable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with symptomatic care and routine prenatal follow-up
Place the patient in airborne isolation and obtain RT-PCR testing
Obtain rubella IgM and IgG serology before implementing any precautions
Implement standard and droplet precautions and immediately notify the health department
Admit for fetal monitoring with contact isolation precautions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharging a patient with suspected rubella without implementing infection control measures would allow the disease to spread. Additionally, rubella is a nationally notifiable disease; public health authorities must be notified of any suspected cases.

B) INCORRECT:

While RT-PCR testing is appropriate for diagnosis, along with rubella serology, airborne precautions are not indicated for rubella.

C) INCORRECT:

Serology is important for diagnosis, but infection control measures and public health notification should not be delayed pending laboratory results. All suspected cases of rubella should be immediately reported to the local or state health department.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Standard and droplet precautions are the most appropriate step in management for patients with suspected rubella as the virus is transmitted via respiratory droplets. Additionally, rubella is a nationally notifiable disease; suspected cases must be reported immediately to the local or state health department without waiting for laboratory confirmation.

E) INCORRECT:

Contact isolation is not required for rubella transmission, which occurs through respiratory droplets. While there is a risk for vertical transmission, immediate admission for fetal monitoring is not the priority in this patient.

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of increasing weakness and a rash that started on his face 2 days ago. The rash spread rapidly and involves the trunk and extremities. Last week, he had a mild sore throat, pink eyes, and a headache. His family recently immigrated from Ethiopia. His immunization status is unknown. The patient appears severely ill. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination shows tender postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. There is a nonconfluent, maculopapular rash over the torso and extremities. Infection with which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rubella is caused by the rubella virus, an RNA virus of the genus Rubivirus (formerly part of the family Togaviridae) and family Matonaviridae. In addition to the exanthem and prodromal symptoms seen in this boy, some patients also have a maculopapular enanthem on the soft palate (Forchheimer sign). Teenagers and adults with rubella often present with polyarthritis as well. Although the infection usually has a benign course and is self-limited, infection during pregnancy can lead to congenital rubella syndrome in the neonate, manifesting with cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss, and heart defects.

The first dose of the MMR vaccine is recommended at 12–15 months of age; a second dose should be administered at 4–6 years of age because of potential nonresponders.

B) INCORRECT:

Varicella zoster virus, or human herpesvirus 3, causes chickenpox (and shingles), which can present with prodromes such as fever and malaise; however, a rash is usually the first sign of infection. The exanthem typically starts on the trunk and subsequently spreads to the entire body, including the scalp and, in some cases, affecting the oral and urogenital mucosa, as well as the palms and soles. The rash presents in various stages (e.g., papules, vesicles, crusts) and is severely pruritic. This patient's maculopapular rash is not consistent with chickenpox.

C) INCORRECT:

Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum or "fifth disease". Patients with erythema infectiosum typically present with mild flu-like symptoms followed by a rash. The exanthem usually begins on the face as a “slapped-cheek rash” with perioral sparing and subsequently spreads to the trunk and extremities. Adults in particular often present with additional symptoms of arthralgia and symmetrical polyarthritis. The examination findings in this case are not consistent with erythema infectiosum.

D) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 6 (and 7) cause exanthem subitum, which manifests with fever and lymphadenopathy. However, exanthem subitum is further characterized by an abrupt onset of high fever, inflamed tympanic membranes, and papular enanthem on the uvula and soft palate (Nagayama spots), which are not seen here. The patchy, rose-pink, confluent, blanching, maculopapular rash seen in exanthem subitum spreads from the trunk to the face and extremities. The rash typically appears 2–3 days after the fever, when patients subsequently experience a sudden decrease in temperature, and can easily go unnoticed as it fades within a few hours to 2 days. The examination findings in this case are not consistent with exanthem subitum.

E) INCORRECT:

Measles is caused by the measles virus, which belongs to the family of Paramyxoviridae. Measles typically present in two stages. The prodromal stage is characterized by a classic triad of coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis in combination with Koplik spots, a typical enanthem of the buccal mucosa. It is followed by an exanthem stage in which patients usually develop a high fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and a maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem that spreads from the face to the entire body. This patient's low-grade fever, nonconfluent rash, and isolated postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy are consistent with another disease.
questions.hint: This young boy presents with a history of prodromal symptoms (sore throat, pink eyes, headache) and a rash behind the ears that quickly developed into a generalized maculopapular exanthem. The overall presentation, in addition to postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy and missing vaccination records, is concerning for infection with a specific virus.
